newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela govt proposes domestic oil opening.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela govt proposes domestic oil opening.

text.p: Venezuela's Ministry of Energy and Mines formally proposed its domestic oil market liberalisation plan to Congress, an official said Thursday.

The proposal, which may still go through many changes, envisages a year's transition to totally free gasoline and diesel markets, during which the government would raise prices in two stages, said vice-Minister of Energy and Mines Evanan Romero.
"This law will allow the modernisation of the sector, opening the internal oil market to private participation," he told journalists.
Lubricants, asphalt and paraffin were already set according to free markets, he added, and this law would affect only gasoline and diesel.

Venezuelan gasoline and diesel are currently kept at about 85 percent of the factory gate price by government subsidies, and state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela (PDVSA) has a monopoly over supply to gasoline stations, which are mostly privately- owned.

The government's plan would remove PDVSA's monopoly and increase retail prices to the factory gate level at the beginning of the transition period, Romero said. During a year, the government would set a fixed margin to retailers and only then free prices completely.

Romero hoped the government's bill would be approved before the end of this year, but expected active debate in parliament. A group of congress officials have drafted a rival bill that would keep some form of state control over the market.
